intro: Androsace sarmentosa var. watkinsii, commonly known as the creeping arete, is a low-growing, mat-forming plant native to the mountainous regions of central Asia. It features small, fleshy leaves that are typically arranged in a rosette pattern, adapted to retain moisture in arid environments. The plant produces clusters of white or pink flowers during the spring and summer months, which attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in well-drained, rocky soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine habitats. Due to its ornamental value and hardiness, it is occasionally cultivated in rock gardens and alpine plant collections.
